thread.title: Panthers look to claw out A-6 victory
thread.title_full: Panthers look to claw out A-6 victory

title: Panthers look to claw out A-6 victory
text:
Panthers look to claw out A-6 victory By Mike Tupa mtupa@examiner-enterprise.com 
Heartbreak, thy alias is Barnsdall High School football. 
No one could blame the Panthers for trying to glue together the pieces of their shattered hopes following last Friday’s 21-20 loss at Mounds. 
The good news, their pumpers are back in working order — and primed to peak determination — for tonight’s home showdown against Morrison. 
“I think it will be one of those game where if we can control the run game and run the ball on them, it will be a very short game,” Barnsdall head coach Clif Warford said Wednesday evening. “That would play on our side.” 
Warford said he’s also grateful for the abbreviated days of practice, between last Friday’s loss and tonight’s tilt. 
“I think the short week benefitted us, knowing that we’ve got a home game coming up,” he explained. “That put last week’s game behind us.” 
Tonight’s District A-6 battle against Morrison (4-2, 1-1) also is vital for Barnsdall’s quest to remain firmly in the playoff chase. 
The Panthers (2-4, 0-3) are trying to break out of a four-game losing spiral, including last week’s oh-so-close effort. 
Barnsdall led in the third quarter, 20-7. Mounds began its rally on a touchdown drive — capped by a fourth-down pass from the five-yard line. 
After getting the ball back, Morrison tallied the tying touchdown — and booted the extra point — with approximately four minutes remaining. 
Barnsdall still had one final opportunity offensively, but their drive sputtered due to a sack and a few incompletions. 
“Our boys played hard,” Warford explained. “We have two fumbles by Mounds that we could have recovered.” 
Both of those missed turnover opportunities occurred during Mounds’ scoring drives. 
“Sometimes, you just don’t get the breaks,” Warford said. 
Panther quarterback James Cole connected on 7-of-14 passes for 63 yards and one of the Panthers’ touchdowns. 
Cole also ran for a touchdown during one of his 14 carries. 
Barnsdall feature runningback Payton McCarty eclipsed the century mark, rumbled for 106 yards — and a touchdown — on 13 totes. 
Receiver Landon Lanphear hauled in just one reception — but it was good for a 21-yard touchdown play. 
McCarty snared one catch for 25 yards and Paul Schmidt fingered four receptions for 15 yards. 
On the defensive side, Colten Allen and McCarty each racked up 12 tackles, followed by Cole, nine; Schmidt, nine; and Wesley Yarber, seven. 
In reality, the Panthers went into that contest with almost one armed tied behind their. Three of their starting defensive backs/receivers sat out, due to injury. 
Even though this trio will be absent again this week, Warford said his defense should match up better against Morrison. 
“Morrison runs a lot of things,” he said. “They have seven or eight, sometimes nine guys on the line. … We definitely are geared toward stopping the run.” 
Barnsdall also gains a new weapon, senior transfer Austin Nelson, who has had to sit out to become eligible to play. Nelson is slated to play in the offensive backfield and at defensive end. 
Nelson’s planned debut has been delayed two weeks, due to injuries, Warford said. 
“It will be good to see his first taste of action,” the coach added. 
Barnsdall will focus more this week on its running game, including lining up at times in a full-house backfield, he added. 
He praised the efforts of Lanphear, Colton Auschwitz and Logan Bryant for stepping into the roles left vacant by the injuries to his secondary players/receivers. 
With the best mix of talent he can field right now, Warford is hoping the Barnsdall can make a U-turn tonight in their season fortunes and move into the fast lane of success.
